snippet: Judge Robert Owen said that it was “inevitable” that part of his final report about the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, would remain secret.
abstract: British Judge Robert Owen opens high-profile inquiry into poisoning death of former KGB officer Alexander V Litvinenko, fierce critic of Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin; says allegations of Moscow’s involvement will be of importance; court will not hear witnesses until January 2015; some hearings in case will be closed, due national security concerns, and some findings will remain secret.
lead_paragraph: Judge Robert Owen said that it was “inevitable” that part of his final report about the 2006 death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, would remain secret.

headline.seo: Alexander Litvinenko’s Death Examined as Ties Fray Between Russia and West
headline.main: Inquiry Into Poisoning of Ex-K.G.B. Officer Opens in Britain
headline.print_headline: Inquiry Into Poisoning of Ex-K.G.B. Officer Opens in Britain
